perturbation.original_text:
XFN may terminate this Agreement by giving thirty (30) days written notice
to the CEIS.
perturbation.changed_text:
XFN may terminate this Agreement by giving ten (10) days written notice
to the CEIS.
perturbation.explanation: Under contract law principles of reasonable notice, especially in international commercial agreements, thirty days is a common benchmark for termination notices. Reducing this to ten days may be deemed unreasonable and could potentially conflict with legal expectations for fair notice, leading to legal challenges.

Many jurisdictions require a reasonable opportunity to cure a breach of contract. While 30 days is typically considered reasonable, reducing the cure period to 10 days may be deemed insufficient, potentially violating principles of good faith and fair dealing implied in contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Opportunity to Cure Breach

perturbation.original_text:
Any notice, demand or other communication so addressed to the
relevant Party shall be deemed to have been delivered (a) if given or made
by letter by hand, when actually delivered to the relevant address against
receipt; (b) if given or made by letter by post, two business days after
posting; and (c) if given or made by fax, when dispatched and received in
good order.
perturbation.changed_text:
Any notice, demand or other communication so addressed to the
relevant Party shall be deemed to have been delivered (a) if given or made
by letter by hand, when actually delivered to the relevant address against
receipt; (b) if given or made by letter by post, one week days after
posting; and (c) if given or made by fax, when dispatched.
perturbation.explanation: Under Hong Kong laws, two business days for postal delivery may be considered reasonable. Delaying that delivery to one week may cause issues that can cause harm to either party. Furthermore, the clause 'and received in good order' ensures transmission success, thus removing it can prove to be an issue.
